metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Training a Perceptron
Training Task
Imagine a straight line in a space with scattered x y points.
content.html: Imagine a straight line in a space with scattered x y points.

content.text: Train a perceptron to classify the points over and under the line.
content.html: Train a perceptron to classify the points over and under the line.

content.text: Create a Perceptron Object
Create a Perceptron object. Name it anything (like Perceptron).
content.html: Create a Perceptron object. Name it anything (like Perceptron).

content.text: Let the perceptron accept two parameters:
content.html: Let the perceptron accept two parameters:

content.text: Set the default learning rate to 0.00001.
content.html: Set the default learning rate to 0.00001.

content.text: Then create random weights between -1 and 1 for each input.
content.html: Then create random weights between -1 and 1 for each input.

content.code_html:
// Perceptron Object
 function Perceptron(no, learningRate = 0.00001) {

// Set Initial Values
 this.learnc = learningRate;
this.bias = 1;

// Compute Random Weights
 this.weights = [];
for (let i = 0; i <= no; i++) {
  this.weights[i] = Math.random() * 2 - 1;
}

// End Perceptron Object
 }

content.text: The Random Weights
The Perceptron will start with a random weight for each input.
content.html: The Perceptron will start with a random weight for each input.

content.text: The Learning Rate
For each mistake, while training the Perceptron, the weights will be adjusted with a small fraction.
content.html: For each mistake, while training the Perceptron, the weights will be adjusted with a small fraction.

content.text: This small fraction is the " Perceptron's learning rate ".
content.html: This small fraction is the "Perceptron's learning rate".

content.text: In the Perceptron object we call it learnc .
content.html: In the Perceptron object we call it learnc.

content.text: The Bias
Sometimes, if both inputs are zero, the perceptron might produce an incorrect output.
content.html: Sometimes, if both inputs are zero, the perceptron might produce an incorrect output.

content.text: To avoid this, we give the perceptron an extra input with the value of 1.
content.html: To avoid this, we give the perceptron an extra input with the value of 1.

content.text: This is called a bias .
content.html: This is called a bias.

content.text: Add an Activate Function
Remember the perceptron algorithm:
content.html: Remember the perceptron algorithm:

content.code_html:
this.activate = function(inputs) {
  let sum = 0;
  for (let i = 0; i < inputs.length; i++) {
    sum += inputs[i] * this.weights[i];
  }
  if (sum > 0) {return 1} else {return 0}
}

content.text: The activation function will output:
content.html: The activation function will output:

content.text: Create a Training Function
The training function guesses the outcome based on the activate function.
content.html: The training function guesses the outcome based on the activate function.

content.text: Every time the guess is wrong, the perceptron should adjust the weights.
content.html: Every time the guess is wrong, the perceptron should adjust the weights.

content.text: After many guesses and adjustments, the weights will be correct.
content.html: After many guesses and adjustments, the weights will be correct.

content.code_html:
this.train = function(inputs, desired) {
  inputs.push(this.bias);
  let guess = this.activate(inputs);
  let error = desired - guess;
  if (error != 0) {
    for (let i = 0; i < inputs.length; i++) {
      this.weights[i] += this.learnc * error * inputs[i];
    }
  }
}

content.text: Backpropagation
After each guess, the perceptron calculates how wrong the guess was.
content.html: After each guess, the perceptron calculates how wrong the guess was.

content.text: If the guess is wrong, the perceptron adjusts the bias and the weights so that the guess will be a little bit more correct the next time.
content.html: If the guess is wrong, the perceptron adjusts the bias and the weights so that the guess will be a little bit more correct the next time.

content.text: This type of learning is called backpropagation .
content.html: This type of learning is called backpropagation.

content.text: After trying (a few thousand times) your perceptron will become quite good at guessing.
content.html: After trying (a few thousand times) your perceptron will become quite good at guessing.

content.text: Create Your Own Library

content.code_html:
// Perceptron Object
 function Perceptron(no, learningRate = 0.00001) {

// Set Initial Values
 this.learnc = learningRate;
this.bias = 1;

// Compute Random Weights
 this.weights = [];
for (let i = 0; i <= no; i++) {
  this.weights[i] = Math.random() * 2 - 1;
}

// Activate Function
 this.activate = function(inputs) {
  let sum = 0;
  for (let i = 0; i < inputs.length; i++) {
    sum += inputs[i] * this.weights[i];
  }
  if (sum > 0) {return 1} else {return 0}
}

// Train Function
 this.train = function(inputs, desired) {
  inputs.push(this.bias);
  let guess = this.activate(inputs);
  let error = desired - guess;
  if (error != 0) {
    for (let i = 0; i < inputs.length; i++) {
      this.weights[i] += this.learnc * error * inputs[i];
    }
  }
}

// End Perceptron Object
 }

content.text: Use Your Library

content.code_html:
// Initiate Values
 const numPoints = 500;
const learningRate = 0.00001;

// Create a Plotter
 const plotter = new XYPlotter("myCanvas");
plotter.transformXY();
const xMax = plotter.xMax;
const yMax = plotter.yMax;
const xMin = plotter.xMin;
const yMin = plotter.yMin;

// Create Random XY Points
 const xPoints = [];
const yPoints = [];
for (let i = 0; i < numPoints; i++) {
  xPoints[i] = Math.random() * xMax;
  yPoints[i] = Math.random() * yMax;
}

// Line Function
 function f(x) {
  return x * 1.2 + 50;
}

//Plot the Line
 plotter.plotLine(xMin, f(xMin), xMax, f(xMax), "black");

// Compute Desired Answers
 const desired = [];
for (let i = 0; i < numPoints; i++) {
  desired[i] = 0;
  if (yPoints[i] > f(xPoints[i])) {desired[i] = 1}
}

// Create a Perceptron
 const ptron = new Perceptron(2, learningRate);

// Train the Perceptron
 for (let j = 0; j <= 10000; j++) {
  for (let i = 0; i < numPoints; i++) {
    ptron.train([xPoints[i], yPoints[i]], desired[i]);
  }
}

// Display the Result
 for (let i = 0; i < numPoints; i++) {
  const x = xPoints[i];
  const y = yPoints[i];
  let guess = ptron.activate([x, y, ptron.bias]);
  let color = "black";
  if (guess == 0) color = "blue";
  plotter.plotPoint(x, y, color);
}
